review.title: Multi-Robot Informative Path Planning for Active Sensing of Environmental Phenomena: A Tale of Two Algorithms
review.abstract: A key problem of robotic environmental sensing and monitoring is that of active sensing: How can a team of robots plan the most informative observation paths to minimize the uncertainty in modeling and predicting an environmental phenomenon? This paper presents two principled approaches to efficient information-theoretic path planning based on entropy and mutual information criteria for in situ active sensing of an important broad class of widely-occurring environmental phenomena called anisotropic fields. Our proposed algorithms are novel in addressing a trade-off between active sensing performance and time efficiency. An important practical consequence is that our algorithms can exploit the spatial correlation structure of Gaussian process-based anisotropic fields to improve time efficiency while preserving near-optimal active sensing performance. We analyze the time complexity of our algorithms and prove analytically that they scale better than state-of-the-art algorithms with increasing planning horizon length. We provide theoretical guarantees on the active sensing performance of our algorithms for a class of exploration tasks called transect sampling, which, in particular, can be improved with longer planning time and/or lower spatial correlation along the transect. Empirical evaluation on real-world anisotropic field data shows that our algorithms can perform better or at least as well as the state-of-the-art algorithms while often incurring a few orders of magnitude less computational time, even when the field conditions are less favorable.

sections.heading: 2.1 Transect Sampling Task
sections.text: In a transect sampling task [14, 24], a team of k robots is assigned to explore and sample an environmental phenomenon spatially distributed over a transect (Fig. 1), which is divided into a r · n grid of sampling points where the number n columns is much greater than the number r sampling points in each column, r will be small in a transect and k ≤ r. The columns are indexed in an increasing order from left to right. k robots are forced to simultaneously explore a column from left column "1" to right column "n" forward, so that each robot tries one place per column for a total of n locations. Therefore, given its current position, each robot can move to any of the places in the adjacent column where it is maneuverable on its right side. In practice, the transit sampling task is particularly suitable and is performed by mobile robots with limited maneuverability.

sections.heading: 2.2 Gaussian Process-Based Anisotropic Field
sections.text: An environmental phenomenon is defined as a realization of a rich class of Bayesian non-parametric models called the Gaussian process (GP) [20] that can formally characterize its spatial correlation structure and be refined with increasing number of observations. More importantly, GP can provide formal measures of predictive uncertainty (e.g., based on an entropy or mutual information criterion) to explore the highly uncertain areas of the phenomenon. sections.text: This section evaluates the active sensor performance and computational efficiency of MEPP (m) (i.e., (7) and (8)) and M2IPP (m) (i.e., (12) and (13)) algorithms empirically on two real-world datasets: (a) May 2009 temperature field data from Panther Hollow Lake in Pittsburgh, PA, spatially distributed over a 25 m x 150 m transect discredited into a 5 x 30 grid [17], and (b) June 2009 plankton density field data from Chesapeake Bay spatially distributed over a 314 m transect discredited into an 8 x 45 grid. These environmental phenomena are modeled by GPs using hyperparameters (i.e., horizontal and vertical longitudinal scales, signal and noise variances) (Section 2.2).

sections.heading: 5.3 Summary of Test Results
sections.text: The observations of the above results are summarized below: For anisotropic fields with low spatial correlation along the transect (e.g. temperature fields a and b and plankton density field), MEPP (m) performs better or at least as well as gMEPP and gM2IPP in the prediction error (i.e. with 3 robots) and entropy metrics with small m-values of 1 or 2, resulting in less time. M2IPP (m) can generally also perform in the prediction error (i.e. with 1 or 2 robots) and mutual information metrics with a small m-value of 1 or 2, resulting in less time (in particular 2 orders of magnitude less time than gM2IPP). These observations are explained above in Section 5.1.1.

sections.heading: 6. CONCLUSION
sections.text: This paper describes two principle-driven information-theoretical path planning algorithms based on entropy and mutual information criteria (MEPP (m) and M2IPP (m)) for active mapping of GP-based anisotropic fields. Two important practical implications derive from the theoretical guarantees for the active mapping performance of our algorithms (theorems 2 and 4): Increasing m leads to an improvement in computing power (theorems 1 and 3) for better active mapping performance, and our algorithms can take advantage of a low spatial correlation along the transect to improve time efficiency (i.e., they require only a small m) while at the same time delivering near-optimal active mapping performance, motivating the use of earlier knowledge, if available, of a low spatial correlation to align it with the horizontal axis of the transect.
